section_purpose: This section concludes the paper by summarizing the study on using GNNs to solve the MaxSAT problem, highlighting key findings, and suggesting directions for future research.
key_points: Graph neural networks (GNNs) are promising for solving combinatorial problems like MaxSAT in a data-driven fashion.
Two GNN models, MS-NSFG and MS-ESFG, were developed and achieved high accuracy on randomly generated benchmarks with good generalization to larger, more difficult instances.
The paper provides a theoretical analysis showing that even a single-layer GNN can solve MaxSAT with an approximation ratio of 1/2.
Future work includes integrating GNN models into search frameworks to handle more complex problems such as weighted and partial MaxSAT.
Another future direction is to analyze the theoretical capability of multilayer GNNs for achieving better approximation ratios.

formulas: Approximation ratio of 1/2 for single-layer GNNs solving MaxSAT problem
datasets: Randomly generated benchmarks with different distributions

dependencies: Preliminaries (SAT and MaxSAT, Graph Neural Networks)
Theoretical Analysis (Algorithmic Alignment, Distributed Local Algorithm)
Experimental Evaluation (Building the Models, Data Generation, Implementation Details)
